content.description: This short but fun moderate just adds to the mileage for the day out while traversing the crag to climb them all. Â Start on a red slab that has a few cryptic balancy moves (or cheat and use the white fin of rock on the left wall) and crimp and layback your way up two clips to the ledge above. 3 more clips up a shallow right facing dihedral to the bolted anchor just over the lip.
content.location: Located right of Brown Nosed Sheep, and just left of The Butt Crack roof.

content.description: Climb north side of tower on low angle except for one reachy bulge that keeps this from being a good kid top rope. Rap off east face to reduce drag.
content.location: North side of tower 20 yards south of main wall.

content.description: Good holds through many small bulges.
content.location: On small Tower 20 yards south of ewe for real wall.

content.description: Climb the deceptively looking, but short headwall through the first bolt, to where the angle backs off, clipping two more bolts before the anchor.
content.location: Located on the far left (south) end of the Ewe For Real Wall, south of the little tower.

content.description:
A well protected route with an "out of this world" feel.

EWE.F.O.

is cosmic climb through space and time. Do you believe?

Begin on a large flake pulling up and right towards the first bolt. Work your way up and into the

extraterrestrial highway

(a three to four foot long handcrack and power lie-back) passing a few more bolts ending on a ledge with a no hands rest. Clip another bolt and continue up into the finale crux. Be precise, and avoid

abduction

. The exit has many

unidentified

options.

Short and sweet.
content.protection: Nine draws for seven bolts and an anchor.
content.location:
Just above the old corral lies a band of rock. Top dead center of the

Corral Crag

is a blob of rock hosting five routes.

EWE.F.O.

is the second in from the left. Look for a hand sized crack at bolt three. This is just right of

Ewe Make It

and just left of

Ewe Betch Ewe

.

content.description:
An anti-classic line up a deceptive arete. Bordeline ridiculous, this route will work your brain and body. Most mortals will spend the first run equipping the route, the second run working out the moves, and the third run sending.

Double cruxed,

Ewe Make It

just barely goes. Easy climbing reaches the first bolt, then a few spacious moves lead to a tough, second clip. The first crux comes at the mid-point range and the last crux comes at the final bulge. With the exception of getting to the second bolt,

Ewe Make It

is well protected. Expect some hard climbing and thoughtful moves on this low-flow, bouldery route. Terribly awkward, this climb is still a lot of fun!
content.protection: Six bolts to set of separate, fixed ring anchors.
content.location:
You'll find

Ewe Make It

on the left side arete of the

Ewe for Real

wall.

climbs.name: Ewe Love It
climbs.fa: Tim Toula and James Garrett, 25 April 2004

content.description:
This climb goes up a left facing corner on the far left side of the

Ewe For Real Wall.

The climb starts on the left side of the face with thin liebacking to a stance that allows you to stem across the gap. Continue up into the slot and move a few feet north to find a flaring crack. Stem up this crack and then push over the top to reach the shared chains with

Ewe Make It

.
content.protection: Takes a variety of cams. A single rack to #1 Camalot is probably sufficient with maybe a couple extra small cams. The bolts on the right can be clipped in a few spots if you want.
content.location:
Look for the left facing corner on the

Ewe For Real Wall

. This climb starts about 5 feet left of

Ewe Make It.

content.description: Strange start getting off the ledge using pinches and tiny edges to the ramp. Plug in a finger size cam then work your way in and out of the scooping overhang clipping bolts.  A fun short route on bullet proof rock with a awsome jug towards the end.
content.protection: 3 bolts, Finger size peice. Shares chain anchors with Ewe for Real
content.location: First route on the right side of this wall.  The route climbs the cool black streak in the overhang.

content.description:
A rad line up a peculiar face. A high bolt leads to a committing move and second clip. After that a few wandering moves out right and around a bulge land you on a slabby, technical, low-angled face. Some well protected crux moves finish this short, perplexing line. Save your brain for the exit.

A nice route,

Ewe for Real

is probably the third best line on the wall.
content.protection: Six bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the fourth bolted line from the left.

content.description:
Ever feel left out of the screaming match between man and boulder? Now's your chance! Hosting an abundance of stacked cruxes,

Ewe Betch Ewe

begins hard and ends even harder.

A few

Watch Me!

moves get things going, a rest is gained at a protection pod and then the real action begins. The Delicate Crux is getting onto the blank face, the Power Crux with a tough clip then  soon follows. Passing two more bolts, gain a ledge with a no hands rest. Next up is the "Whoa Nelly" Crux, recharge on the ledge and get creative. Balance, finesse, power and luck will get you through....can you do it?

EWE BETCH EWE

can!

Intense and involved.
content.protection: A #2 camalot and draws for six bolts and a chain anchor. Finish up and right on Ewe for Real anchor.
content.location:
Just above the old corral lies a band of rock. Top dead center of the

Corral Crag

is a 60 foot tall blob hosting five routes.

Ewe Betch Ewe

is the third bolted route in from the left.  Look for a hand sized pod after bolt one. This is just right of

EWE.F.O.

and just left of

Ewe for Real

.

content.description: This is a fun handcrack with some great jams and excellent gear. Climb the two steep sections to a final short pull to the right which let you clip the chains.
content.protection: Hand size pieces. Nothing larger than a #3 or smaller than a #.75.
content.location: This climb faces north just around the corner to the right from the other Ewe-themed routes. Step up onto the small boulders and the climb becomes obvious. Chain anchors can be seen at the top of the route.
